title: Mismatched delimiters recovered incorrectly

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: A-parser
labels.description: Area: The parsing of Rust source code to an AST.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
fn main(){
    let x = a.map(|)| s);
}
```
which has a typo `_` -> `)`.

The compiler gives this error:
```
error: unexpected closing delimiter: `}`
 --> src/main.rs:3:1
  |
3 | }
  | ^ unexpected closing delimiter

error: mismatched closing delimiter: `)`
 --> src/main.rs:2:24
  |
1 | fn main(){
  |          - unclosed delimiter
2 |     let x = a.map(|)| s);
  |                        ^ mismatched closing delimiter
```

The first error is not helpful. In fact, `}` is well-paired. This error is misleading as this causes developers to check `{}` pairs instead of `()`. In some more complicated files, there might be more errors related to this issue, so the real error (mismatched `()`) is displayed further in the bottom and confuses developers further.

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
1.46.0-nightly (2020-06-12)
```
